<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_irq_register_controller:
```c
int metal_irq_register_controller(struct metal_irq_controller *cntr)
{
	int irq_base;
	struct metal_list *node;

	if (cntr == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	metal_list_for_each(&irq_cntrs, node) {
		if (node == &cntr->node) {
			return 0;
		}
	}

	/*
	 * Allocate IRQ numbers which are not yet used by any IRQ
	 * controllers.
	 */
	irq_base = metal_irq_allocate(cntr->irq_base, cntr->irq_num);
	if (irq_base == METAL_IRQ_ANY) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	cntr->irq_base = irq_base;

	metal_list_add_tail(&irq_cntrs, &cntr->node);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only potential for-statement in this function is the invocation of the metal_list_for_each macro. Its expansion is not visible here, so the generated for statement must be inspected to ensure it meets Rule 14.2 (correct first/second/third clauses, single loop counter not modified in the body, second clause has no persistent side effects and only uses the loop counter and allowed flags). The inner if/return inside that loop is flagged because early return from the loop body may interact with loop-counter modification rules (and any functions called inside the loop body must also be considered part of the loop behaviour). No other for loops or loop-like constructs are present in the provided code. Other fragments (the NULL check, calls to metal_irq_allocate, assignment to cntr->irq_base, metal_list_add_tail, and the final return) are simple statements that do not form or contain a for statement and do not by themselves affect the well-formedness of a for loop per Rule 14.2, so they do not need investigation for this specific rule.
